body: @tqchen Can you close this issue? Let me open a new one.

@tqchen I apologize that I did not push the migration which made that issue stale.
Can you close the old one and we discuss here?

I think a bit more about this. Given that deep learning is a well-received topic and most likely readers can already find materials by searching online, we may not have to include links to materials here. As the project's goal is not to curate a comprehensive list for this topic.

@tqchen as per the request the signature in C++ side is runtime::TypedPackedFunc<Expr()>
I have updated it in above as well.

@MarisaKirisame can you give a specific comment on how is this FGradient expected to be used?
```TypedPackedFunc<Expr()>``` does not really make sense because it does not take in input expressions. 

I think the signature should be like the follows
```c++
TypedPackedFunc<Array<Expr> (Expr orig_call, Expr out_grad)>
```
- Take in original call node, out_grad, and output, return a list of gradient wrt to each input
@tqchen it is a function expression taking orig_call, and will return a tuple. the right hand side will take out_grad. (it is a function in relay but not a function in C++).

I see what you mean, it is possible to express simple function's gradient purely in relay. So conceptually, it is more like:

```c++
TypedPackedFunc<RelayFunc<Tuple<Expr>(Expr out_grad)> (Expr orig_call)>
```

Is there any specific motivation to actually construct gradient in this way? Can we discuss the pros/cons of the alternatives? Note that, we will need to have a C++ function that takes in orig_call, because we will need to handle attributes to the primitive calls, like axis in ```sum(x, axis=1)```
That makes sense. Closing this pr.
okay, I will look into this.
@tqchen i just checked and it is post order. I will update the comment.

I think this is a great change.

I've run into this problem multiple times, and having a consistent default would be good.
is this for Mask R-CNN? Very interesting!
@masahi Yes, I'm also working on other ops for Mask R-CNN

I have recursive merging in, but I think each merge also needs to propagate in order for the rel lists to be correctly updated (since it is always true that if a type has nested types, updates to the nested types should cause updates to relations for the parent). I am getting some weird problems with circular links being formed, so I think I will try using different data structures to both eliminate the issue of circular links and make it easier to keep the trigger lists up to date (a lot of wacky visitors going around).

(This will probably lead to some inefficiencies, but I'd rather have things be obviously correct and ready for us to fix later than subtly flawed.)
@jroesch @joshpoll @tqchen please take a look.

Thanks for working on the text format! There are definitely a lot of gaps that need to be filled. In fact I think the parser can't handle recursive local functions either right now.

I think this is a problem with the parser, not with the module interface. In my opinion, it would be better to solve this issue by adding a dict from GlobalVar to Optional[Function] in the parser, which would serve as an in-progress version of the module. In visitDefn, we'd add the GlobalVar to the dict (mapped to None) before visiting the function and then updating the function value in the dict. Finally in visitProg we could turn this dict into a Relay Module.

Additionally, although this wasn't introduced by this PR, I'm confused why we're using `name_hint` for equality in `module.cc` even though users are warned in multiple places not to use it for that purpose. Either we need to rewrite `module.cc` or change the comments.

Hey, @joshpoll I'm not sure if your suggestion would fix the issue. Let me expand a little bit. Let's use a simple program as example:
````
 def @id(%x: int32) -> int32 {
            let %v1 = @id(%x);
            let %v2 = @id(%x);
            %v2
 }
````
The 2 occurrences of `@id` inside function body corresponds to different `GlobalVar` objects. So if we use object identity as key to look up `GlobalVar`, either one of the function call will fail during `InferType` on calling `ModuleNode::Lookup`.  This is the stacktrace in current mainline with my unit test:
````
TVMError: [16:03:31] /Users/wweic/workspace/tvm/src/relay/ir/module.cc:78: Check failed: it != functions.end() There is no definition of id

Stack trace returned 10 entries:
[bt] (0) 0   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000115cbf7f0 dmlc::StackTrace(unsigned long) + 512
[bt] (1) 1   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000115cbf4a4 dmlc::LogMessageFatal::~LogMessageFatal() + 52
[bt] (2) 2   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000116074bec tvm::relay::ModuleNode::Lookup(tvm::relay::GlobalVar const&) + 236
[bt] (3) 3   libtvm.dylib                        0x000000011624fed9 tvm::relay::TypeInferencer::VisitExpr_(tvm::relay::GlobalVarNode const*) + 329
[bt] (4) 4   libtvm.dylib                        0x000000011601dc10 std::__1::__function::__func<tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>::InitVTable()::'lambda2'(tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*), std::__1::allocator<tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>::InitVTable()::'lambda2'(tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*)>, tvm::relay::Value (tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*)>::operator()(tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Value (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*&&) + 32
[bt] (5) 5   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000116252849 tvm::IRFunctor<tvm::relay::Type (tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Type (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*)>::operator()(tvm::NodeRef const&, tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Type (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>*) const + 345
[bt] (6) 6   libtvm.dylib                        0x000000011624f5c7 tvm::relay::ExprFunctor<tvm::relay::Type (tvm::relay::Expr const&)>::VisitExpr(tvm::relay::Expr const&) + 119
[bt] (7) 7   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000116249c56 tvm::relay::TypeInferencer::GetType(tvm::relay::Expr const&) + 86
[bt] (8) 8   libtvm.dylib                        0x000000011625597a tvm::relay::TypeInferencer::GeneralCall(tvm::relay::CallNode const*, tvm::Array<tvm::relay::Type, void>) + 74
[bt] (9) 9   libtvm.dylib                        0x0000000116251127 tvm::relay::TypeInferencer::VisitExpr_(tvm::relay::CallNode const*) + 1111

````

My solution is based on the language design that global vars are unique,  as long as global vars have the same `name_hint`, they should be fine to get resolved to the same `GlobalVar` object. I think that's also why `ModuleNode::GetGlobalVar` works.

Also by fixing the issue in `module.cc`, every API that relies on symbol resolution would get the fix automatically. For example if user manually construct a relay AST then call `InferType`, it will also get fixed.

Right I think I understand the issue, but it has already been resolved for local variables in the parser. Since local and global vars have the same equality mechanism, I think the solutions should be the same. Right now, as you've mentioned, the parser always generates a new GlobalVar when it encounters one; however, this is not how it handles Vars. For local variables, the parser keeps track of scopes and looks up local variables as needed. My proposal is to do something similar for global variables. Ideally we would be able to just use the module to look up global vars, but since the module is write-once, we need to use the strategy I suggested earlier.

To further clarify,

```
let %id = fn (%x: int32) -> int32 { %x };
let %f = fn () { %id(1) };
()
```
parses fine, because `id` is in scope and has been resolved using `self.var_scopes`, but

```
def @id(%x: int32) -> int32 { %x }
def @f() { @id(1) }
```
doesn't parse, since `id` is created fresh and there is currently no mechanism for looking up global vars. My solution is simply to add a lookup mechanism to parser similar to that for local vars, but that also constructs the Module.

As for the second point about fixing it in `module.cc`, the equality issue is the same as for Vars, which we already expect users to deal with. It's worth revisiting equality, but IMO if we decide to use `name_hint` equality for GlobalVars, it should be changed in the class definition in `expr.h`, not in `module.cc`.

@joshpoll Thanks, Just took a look at the local variable implementation :-). `var_scope` enqueues/dequeues as the lexical scope enters/exit through let binding. And lookup uses string name of local var for looking up.

I think I'm getting your point. Are you suggesting that add a scope similar to `var_scope` that maps string to `GlobalVar` objects, and always lookup first in this place?:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/3516cbe0049c7e11ee58afbc668acddb1f110ece/python/tvm/relay/_parser.py#L143

So that `@id` maps to the same object universally instead of one object per occurrence(similar to local variable)? I think it would be better to just show you the code, will work on it soon.

@joshpoll I updated the code, and it does the symbol resolution in parser. Could you take a look?

As a side note,  we currently don't have [mutual recursion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_recursion). And I think it worths another PR to add that, don't plan to add it in this PR.


Thanks @vinx13 @FrozenGene, this is merged!

Out of curiosity have you guys ever considered rather than having gradient functions (which usually define Reverse Mode AD) to have lambdas which construct the whole Jacobian operator. This allows for automatically getting both Forward and Reverse mode AD. Of course one would not "explicitely" store the whole Jacobian, but just construct the linear operator. E.g. for matmul:

```
z = matmul(x, y)
jacobian_dz_dx = implicit_kron(y, identity)
jacobian_dz_dy = implicit_kron(identity, transpose(x))
```
Here `implicit_kron` should not represent an actual operator that constructs the kronecker product, but rather defining an object that can compute efficiently the linear operator actions. 

> First-order AD can be easily optimized and does not require any further language features beyond gradients for operators. Higher-order AD in the manner of demyst would require us to add OCaml-style references to Relay, which we plan to submit soon as a PR.

@MarisaKirisame could you clarify this point? It seems very counterintuitive that somehow first order derivatives are "more special" then any other order. Technically differentiation should be something applicable to any graph, regardless if it comes from differentiation or not.

I think `functions` and `global_var_map_` should be always kept in sync, whenever we add a function, it should be reflected in `global_var_map_` as well, is it a fair assumption? 

This is the reason why add the wrapper here:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/8dd928c7092f76a98fe79e564bbb018c9cca278a/src/relay/pass/type_infer.cc#L546

I think I understand what's going on now. I'm not super familiar with that part of the code base so I'll defer to others if they have thoughts, but it does seem like a good idea.

A couple of others thoughts:

Notice that `TypeInfer` is speculatively typechecking `func` so you should replace the teardown code with a call to `Remove` to get rid of the entries in both maps.

It also seems like `Add` is the only place that uses this speculative version of the `TypeInfer` function. It might make sense to move that function completely inside `module.cc` and use the other `TypeInfer` to do type inference.

@joshpoll Nice advice about `Remove`, changed in latest revision. 

@tqchen @jroesch Could you take a look at type inferencer side part of my change?

@botev 
Higher order here mean AD in higher order language. It is indeed true that higher order AD of first order program need no further feature. We value the closure property (befor/after AD is in the same language) so for whatever AD algorithm you choose we can hopefully do it multiple time.

Sorry for the confusion, i had updated the RFC.

We had not thought about supporting forward mode as of right now, as our main priority is to get back propagation working.

I reported this issue in the post you mentioned [here](https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/vulkan-deploy-issue-with-latest-code/604/7).

> Use debug runtime to run up to k-steps, dump to local files ...

I was looking for mechanisms to support this from C++ (asked [here](https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/layer-serialization-from-c/1406)).   Can you share any pointers or examples that might help illustrate how to perform such logging from C++?

You can setup an  RPC server in the mobile and use https://docs.tvm.ai/api/python/graph_runtime.html#tvm.contrib.graph_runtime.GraphModule.debug_get_output to get k-th output. Then you can just log the output using numpy's typical serialization mechanism

Thanks.  That pointed me in the right direction.  I'm able to use the same mechanism from C++ with `tvm.graph_runtime_debug.create` and the `get_output_by_layer` packaged function calls.

https://gist.github.com/headupinclouds/d87df2dcc9603589b3b9b9cb00f26011#file-tvm_deploy_gpu_sample-cpp-L521

If I use `opt_level=0` the example does return the correct result on the same Android device.  It is only when `opt_level > 0` where things break down.

```
with nnvm.compiler.build_config(opt_level=0):
    graph, lib, params = nnvm.compiler.build(sym, target, shape_dict, params=params, target_host=target_host)
```

The same code with `opt_level=3` (any >= 1) works on Android with `llvm` (cpu) and on the Ubuntu host for all tested back-ends: `llvm` (cpu), `OpenGL`, `Vulkan`, `OpenCL`, and `gpu` (cuda).

I'll see if I can understand the root cause.

There are certainly tradeoffs we can make here. Supporting more meta-data query will make the module more informative, but never-the-less creates additional APIs that need to maintain and part of the code that need to be included in the runtime(which somewhat goes against minimalist principle).

This additional information can also be provided as a wrapper on the current API, for example, storing additional meta-data in json, in the case of REST. For other applications, we already have a convention on name/index of input, as well as the shape info, so such may not be necessary.

@tqchen thanks for review, sorry for the late response, I was on a holidays.
I've updated the patch regarding to your comments:
1. Separated the traced machinery from tvm_packed.
2. The traced value passes as the last argument when lowering.
3. Added additional conditional branch for return value in codegen. In case the TVMRetValue is zero we return traced value, otherwise we return the value specified by the user. In this case it's easy for user to redefine the traced value from python code:
```
@tvm.register_func("call_back")
def call_back(x):
   print (x)
   return user_defined_value
```
Also tests added for that functional too.
I will be appreciate for any feedback.
Thanks.

Maybe this is not in the scope of this RFC or extra work needs to be added, but can this feature be extended to support AD in imperative programming? NNVM is able to achieve that purpose and that's how it works in MXNet/Gluon APIs. Just want to make sure this design has taken imperative programming into consideration.

Eventually, can we achieve the UX as in https://github.com/HIPS/autograd?

Here're my thoughts about a `common` crate:

The main difference (besides some conversions and using a fat point) between frontend and runtime `TVMArgValue` and `TVMRetValue` is how they're wrapping/using `TVMValue`. The runtime `TVMValue`  is raw, however, frontend needs `Debug + Display` and some idiomatic conversions. Therefore, `common`'s `TVMValue` has to be wrapped *at least*. 

Because bindgen doesn't work for runtime, so either we should 
* include the generated raw c api in `common` entirely (same as runtime) 
or 
* include what needed such as raw `TVMValue` and `TVMTypeCode` and then, wrap and impl required conversions for *both* runtime and frontend (because of Orphan rule so that we won't need more wrapper boilerplates in either crates).
